A SURVEY OF THE NEEDS OF EDUCATION
FOR TELEVISION SPECTRUM SPACE
This is important to you, and to everyone in the field of education in
the United States.
The Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission has called
upon education to document the needs of education for television spectrum
space. He has indicated that unless such evidence is available in the forth¬
coming allocation proceedings, education might be seriously slighted in the
new assignments, and might be permanently deprived of its present reserva¬
tions.
Approximately 10 years ago the educational community, in a joint effort,
persuaded the FCC to set aside a portion of the established television spectrum
for the general use of education.
At that time few among us could begin to envision the potential need of
television frequencies for educational purposes. Our demands for spectrum
reservations were based mainly upon optimism and experimental fervor; but
no one really knew what our needs were, or would be, for television frequencies.
During these ten years the development of the use of television, in all its
phases, for education has been impressive, and the obvious potential use and
need has grown beyond anything dreamed of when the original allocations were
made. In spite of this, we, as an educational community within the nation, still
have much to learn about our real as well as our projected needs for television0
We must know much more about how such needs could or should be met.
Failure to acquire such knowledge would be, to say the least, dangerous to the
full development of television for education.
The FCC has stated that the matter of television allocations is its number
one problem, despite the fact that the Commission and Congressional Committees
have been working on it for the past five years.
